Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during rain detections and falling temperatures indicate correct system response to real-time rainfall
Description: Cooling from rainfall signals the system to reduce watering automatically.
short rationale: Appropriate rain response; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during rain detections with rising humidity indicate strong atmospheric moisture alignment
Description: The system correctly interprets increasing humidity and rainfall as signs to pause irrigation.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during no rain detections and falling humidity indicate dryness-driven irrigation behavior
Description: Dry air conditions prompt the system to increase irrigation output.
short rationale: Dry-air driven boosts; low privacy impact.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during rising temperature and no rain detections indicate heat-driven irrigation scaling
Description: The system compensates for evaporative losses caused by high temperatures.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during high humidity and stable temperatures reflect environmental moisture sufficiency
Description: The system conserves water because atmospheric conditions reduce plant water needs.
short rationale: Moisture sufficiency cutbacks; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during high humidity and no rain detections indicate forecast-based rainfall expectation
Description: The system reduces watering based on predicted rainfall even before it occurs.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during low humidity and stable temperatures indicate atmospheric drying rather than thermal triggers
Description: Humidity changes alone cause irrigation scaling even without temperature shifts.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation decreases during temperature drops despite no rain detections indicate cooling-induced evapotranspiration reduction
Description: Cooler air reduces drying, prompting reduced irrigation cycles.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during rapid humidity drops and rising temperatures represent dual-condition dryness detection
Description: The system detects both hotter air and drier atmosphere and boosts irrigation accordingly.
short rationale: Dual dryness triggers; low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during rain detections and humidity spikes indicate system alignment with storm activity
Description: The combination of rainfall and humid air cues the system to cut irrigation.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during humidity rises and no rain detections indicate misinterpretation of atmospheric moisture
Description: Humidity alone might be misread as dryness or does not influence the system correctly.
short rationale: Potential misread of humidity; moderate operational concern.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during warm, humid conditions and no rain detections suggest tropical evapotranspiration patterns
Description: Even humid air cannot offset plant moisture loss under warm climates.
short rationale: Warm/humid still needing irrigation; low sensitivity.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during cold, dry conditions indicate temperature-weighted logic
Description: Cold air suppresses evapotranspiration more than dry air raises it.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during cold, dry conditions and no rain detections indicate algorithm compensation for dry winter air
Description: Dryness outweighs low temperatures in system logic.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during rainfall without major temperature change indicate light or warm rainfall events
Description: Rainfall contributes moisture but does not significantly lower air temperature.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during rainfall with rising temperature indicate warm-season storm behavior
Description: Warm rainfall may occur during convective storms, increasing evapotranspiration before cooling arrives.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during rainfall with stable humidity indicate light rain insufficient to alter atmospheric moisture
Description: The system reacts to rainfall detection even when humidity remains unchanged.
short rationale: Rain detection with little humidity change; modest detail.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during no rain detections and temperature spikes represent diurnal irrigation adjustments
Description: Heat events trigger irrigation cycles even without rainfall changes.
short rationale: Diurnal heat response; low privacy impact.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation decreases during humid nights and no rain detections indicate dew formation reducing irrigation need
Description: Nocturnal moisture reduces environmental stress despite lack of rain.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during dry nights and no rain detections indicate nighttime atmospheric desiccation
Description: Dry nighttime air prompts irrigation even with lower temperatures.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during morning humidity spikes and rain detections indicate early-morning storm patterns
Description: High humidity and rainfall together reduce irrigation needs at dawn.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during afternoon humidity drops and no rain detections indicate peak daytime moisture loss
Description: Irrigation rises to compensate for afternoon atmospheric drying.
short rationale: Afternoon drying response; low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation decreases during cold fronts with rising humidity even without rainfall indicate pre-rainfall moisture accumulation
Description: Humidity increases ahead of storms, reducing irrigation demand before rainfall hits.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during warm fronts with falling humidity and no rain detections indicate incoming dry-air masses
Description: Front-driven atmospheric drying triggers irrigation scaling.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during extended rain detection periods indicate accurate wet-season response
Description: The system adapts well to prolonged moisture availability.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during extended no-rain periods and falling humidity indicate seasonal drought onset
Description: Atmospheric dryness trends signal the need for increased irrigation.
short rationale: Drought onset triggers; low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during extended rain detection periods despite stable temperatures indicate rain-dominant system logic
Description: Rain detection alone is sufficient for irrigation cutbacks regardless of temperature.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during variable humidity and temperature conditions with no rain detections suggest forecast-driven or soil-based triggers
Description: Environmental signals may be inconsistent, leading the system to rely on predictive or secondary inputs.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during rain detections and decreasing temperatures suggest strong storm cooling effects
Description: Cooling coincides with rainfall, reinforcing irrigation reduction decisions.
short rationale: Strong storm cues reducing irrigation; minimal sensitivity.
